text: We were talking about earlier at the beginning of the session was something called global
quantization.
And now let's point this out and talk a little bit further about exactly what this powerful
feature does inside SessionView.
So global quantization, which is right here, has a drop down menu.
I can look at a number of values here.
The default is one bar.
And all this means is that whenever I'm clicking something or asking something to launch inside
SessionView, it's going to follow whatever I have in this drop down menu.
And it's one of these things that really sets Ableton apart and changes your workflow and
your engagement in your tracks.
It's the kind of thing where I can take somebody else's track or my own track and start performing
live with it.
Or what I can do is even in my own tracks, it brings out more of a kind of a performance
in the studio.
So let's dive in a bit deeper into global quantization and take a look at some of its
functions.
So we have our drop down menu here.
Again, we notice that the default was set to one bar.
Now we can play with that or we can do a smaller increment or denomination here like an eighth
note.
And what this does is it just enables me to launch things quicker.
And let's just trigger a few things on the fly and see what happens.
And let's see exactly what we can do to make this piece a little bit different from the
original.
I can go and stop each clip individually if I want to as well.
